sp.p: So well drest, so boon mein, so eloquent, so unaffected, so easie, so free, so particular, so agreeable—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, so, so, there.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O Lord, I beseech you, Madam, don't—

sp.speaker: Ldy P.
sp.p: So gay, so graceful, so good teeth, so fine shape, so fine limbs, so fine linen, and I don't doubt but you have a very good skin, Sir.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Madam— I'm quite out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And my Lady's quite out of Breath; or else you should hear— Gad's bud, you may talk of my Lady Froth.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O fie, fie, not to be named of a day— my Lady Froth is very well in her Accomplishments— but it is when my Lady Plyant is not thought of— if that can ever be.

sp.speaker: Ldy P.
sp.p: O you overcome me— that is so excessive—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Nay, I swear and vow that was pretty.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O, Sir Paul, you are the happiest man alive. Such a Lady! that is the envy of her Sex, and the admiration of ours.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Your humble Servant, I am I thank Heaven in a fine way of living, as I may say, peacefully and happily, and I think need not envy any of my Neighbours, blessed be Providence—
ay, truly, Mr. Careless, my Lady is a great Blessing, a fine, discreet, well-spoken woman as you shall see— if it becomes me to say so; and we live very comfortably together; she's a little hasty sometimes, and so am I; but mine's soon over, and then I'm so sorry— O, Mr. Careless, if it were not for one thhing—

div.stage: Enter Boy with a Letter, carries it to Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Ldy P.
sp.p: How often have you been told of that you Jack-a-napes?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Gad so, Gad's bud— Tim. carry it to my Lady, you should have carry'd it to my Lady first.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis directed to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, well, my Lady reads all Letters first— Child, do so no more; d'ye hear, Tim?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, an please you.

div.stage: Carries the Letter to my Lady and Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A humour of my wife's, you know women have little sancies— But as I was telling you, Mr. Careless, if it were not for one thing, I should think my self the happiest man in the World; indeed that touches me near, very near.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: What can that be, Sir Paul?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, I have, I thank Heaven, a very plentiful Fortune, a good Estate in the Country, some houses in Town, and some money, a pretty tolerable personal Estate; and it is a great grief to me, indeed it is Mr. Careless, that I have not a Son to inherit this— 'Tis true I have a Daughter, and a fine dutiful Child she is, though I say it, blessed be Providence I may say; for indeed, Mr. Careless, I am mightily beholding to Providence—— a poor unworthy Sinner— But if I had a Son, ah, that's my affliction, and my only affliction; indeed I cannot refrain Tears when it comes in my mind.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why, methinks that might be easily remedied— my Lady's a fine likely Woman—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh, a fine likely Woman as you shall see in a Summers day— indeed she is, Mr. Careless, in all respects.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: And I should not have taken you to have been so old—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Alas, that's not it, Mr. Careless; ah! that's not it; no, no, you shoot wide of the mark a mile; indeed you do, that's not it, Mr. Careless; no, no, that's not it.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: No, what can be the matter then?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: You'll scarcely believe me, when I shall tell you why my Lady is so nice— it's very strange, but it's true: too true— she's so very nice, that I don't believe she would touch a Man for the World— at least not above once a year; I'm sure I have found it so; and alas, what's once a year to an Old Man, who would do good in his Generation? indeed it's true, Mr. Careless, it breaks my heart— I am her Husband, as I may say, though far unworthy of that honour, yet I am her Husband; but alas-a-day, I have no more familiarity with her Person— as to that matter— than with my own Mother— no indeed.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Alas-a-day, this is a lamentable story; my Lady must be told on't; she must i'faith, Sir Paul; 'tis an injury to the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ah! would to Heav'n you would, Mr. Careless; you are mightily in her favour.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I warrant you, what we must have a Son some way or other.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Indeed, I should be mightily bound to you, if you could bring it about, Mr. Careless.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Here, Sir Paul, it's from your Steward, here's a return of 600 Pounds; you may take fifty of it for your next half year.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: How does my Girl? come hither to thy Father, poor Lamb, thou'rt melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p:
Heav'n, Sir Paul, you amaze me, of all things in the World— you are never pleased but when we are all upon the broad grin, all laugh and no Company; ah, then 'tis such a
sight to see some teeth— sure you're a great admirer of my Lady Whifler, Mr. Sneer, and Sir Laurence Loud, and that gang.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I vow and swear she's a very merry Woman, but I think she laughs a little too much.

sp.speaker: Ld F.
sp.p: Merry! O Lord, what a character that is of a Woman of Quality— you have been at my Lady Whifler's upon her day, Madam?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord— I must humour this Fool.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: Well and how? hee! what is your sense of the Conversation there?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: O most ridiculous, a perpetual consort of laughing without any harmony; for sure, my Lord, to laugh out of time, is as disagreeable as to sing out of time or out of tune.

sp.speaker: Ld.
sp.p: Hee, hee, hee, right; and then my Lady Whifler is so ready— she always comes in three bars too soon— and then, what do they laugh at? For you know laughing without a jest is as impertinent; hee! as, as—

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: As dancing without a Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Ld.
sp.p: Just 'ifaith, that was at my tongues end.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: But that cannot be properly said of them, for I think they are all in good nature with the World, and only laugh at one another; and you must allow they have all jests in their Persons, though they have none in their Conversation.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: True, as I'm a Person of Honour— for Heaven's sake let us sacrifice 'em to mirth a little.

div.stage: Enter Boy and wispers Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: 'Gads so— Wife, Wife, my Lady Plyant, I have a word.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Ply.
sp.p: I'm busie, Sir Paul, I wonder at your impertinence—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Sir Paul, harkee, I'm reasoning the matter you know; Madam,— if your Ladyship please, we'll discourse of this in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: O ●…o, I wish you good success, I wish you good success. Boy, tell my Lady, when she has done, I would speak with her below.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Froth.
sp.p: Then you think that Episode between Susan, the Dairymaid, and our Coach-man is not amiss; you know, I may suppose the Dairy in Town, as well as in the Country.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Incomparable, let me perish— but then being an Heroick Poem, had not you better call him a Charioteer? Charioteer sounds great; besides your Ladyship's Coach-man having a red face, and you comparing him to the Sun— and you know the Sun is call'd Heav'ns Charioteer.

sp.speaker: Ldy. F.
sp.p: Oh, infinitely better; I'm extremely beholding to you for the hint, stay we'll read over those half a score lines again.
Let me see here, you know what goes before, the comparison, you know.
sp.l: For as the Sun shines every day,
So of our Coach-man I may say.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I'm afraid that simile wont do in wet Weather— because you say the Sun shines every day.

sp.speaker: Ldy. F.
sp.p: No, for the Sun it wont, but it will do for the Coachman, for you know there's most occasion for a Coach in wet Weather.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Right, right, that saves all.

sp.speaker: Ldy. F.
sp.p: Then I don't say the Sun shines all the day, but, that he peeps now and then, yet he does shine all the day too, you know, tho' we don't see him.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Right, but the vulgar will never comprehend that.

sp.speaker: Ldy. F.
sp.p: Well you shall hear— let me see.
sp.l: For as the Sun shines every day,
So, of our Coach-man I may say,
He shows his drunken fiery Face,
Iust as the Sun does, more or less.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: That's right, all's well, all's well.
sp.l: And when at night his labour's done,
Then too like Heav'ns Charioteer, the Sun:
sp.p: Ay, Charioteer does better.
sp.l: Into the Dairy he descends,
And there his whipping and his driving ends;
There he's secure from danger of a bilk,
His fare is paid him, and he sets in Milk.
sp.p: For Susan, you know, is Thetis, and so—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Incomparable well and proper, Igad— but I have one exception to make.— don't you think bilk (I know its good Rhime) but don't you think bilk and fare too like a Hackney Coach-man?

sp.speaker: Ldy. F.
sp.p: I swear and vow I'm afraid so— And yet our Iehu was a Hackney Coach-man, when my Lord took him.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Was that he then, I'm answered, if Iehu was a Hackney Coach-man— you may put that into the marginal Notes, tho' to prevent Criticisms— only mark it with a small asterism, and say,— Iehu was formerly a Hackney Coach-man.

sp.speaker: Ldy. F.
sp.p: I will; you'd oblige me extremely to write Notes to the whole Poem.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: With all my Heart and Soul, and proud of the vast honour, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.p: Hee, hee, hee, my Dear, have you done— wont you joyn with us, we were laughing at my Lady Whister, and Mr. Sneer.

sp.speaker: Ldy. F.
sp.p: — Ay my Dear— were you? Oh filthy Mr. Sneer; he's a nauseous figure, a most fulsamick Fop, Foh— he spent two days together in going about Covent Garden to suit the lining of his Coach with his complexion.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: O silly! yet his Aunt is as fond of him, as if she had brought the Ape into the World her self.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Who, my Lady Toothless; O, she's a mortifying Spectacle; she's always chewing the Cud like an old Yew.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Fie Mr. Brisk, 'tis Eringo's for her Cough.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: I have seen her take 'em half chew'd out of her Mouth, to Laugh, and then put 'em in again— Foh.

sp.speaker: Lord Fr.
sp.p: Foh.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: Then she's always ready to Laugh when Sneer offers to speak—— And sits in expectation of his no Jest, with her Gums bare, and her Mouth open.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Like an Oyster at low Ebb, I'gad— ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Well, I find there are no Fools so inconsiderable in themselves, but they can render other People contemptible in exposing their Infirmities.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Then that t'other great strapping Lady— I can't hit of her Name; the old fat Fool that Paints so exorbitantly.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I know whom you mean— But Deuce take me, I can't hit of her Name neither— Paints de'e say? Why she lays it on with a Trowel— Then she has a great Beard that bristles through it, and makes her look as if she were plaistred with Lime and Hair, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Oh you made a Song upon her, Mr Brisk.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: He? e'gad, so I did— My Lord can sing it.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O good my Lord let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: 'Tis not a Song neither— it's a sort of an Epigram, or rather an Epigrammatick Sonnet; I don't know what to call it, but it's Satyr.— Sing it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. F.
sp.l: Ancient Phillis, has young Graces,
'Tis a strange thing, but a true one;
Shall I tell you how?
She her self makes her own Faces,
And each Morning wears a new one;
Where's the Wonder now?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Short, but there's Salt in't, my way of writing I'gad.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Your Ladiships Chair is come.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: Is Nurse and the Child in it?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: O the dear Creature! Let's go see it.

sp.speaker: Lord F.
sp.p: I swear, my Dear, you'll spoil that Child, with sending it to and again so often, this is the seventh time the Chair has gone for her to Day.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: O-law, I swear it's but the sixth,— and I han't seen her these two hours.—— The poor dear Creature— If wear, my Lord, you don't Love poor little Sapho— Come, my dear Cynthia, Mr. Brisk, we'll go see Sapho, tho' my Lord wont.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I'll wait upon your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, how old is Lady Sapho?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Three Quarters, but I swear she has a World of Wit, and can sing a Tune already? My Lord wont you go? Wont you? What not to see Saph? Pray, My Lord, come see little Saph. I knew you cou'd not stay.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: 'Tis not so hard to counterfeit Joy in the depth of Affliction, as to dissemble Mirth in Company of Fools— Why should I call 'em Fools? The World thinks better of 'em; for these have Quality and Education, Wit and fine Conversation are receiv'd and admir'd by the World— If not, they like and admire themselves— And why is not that true Wisdom, for 'tis Happiness: And for ought I know, we have misapply'd the Name all this while, and mistaken the thing: Since
sp.l: If Happiness in Self-content is plac'd,
The Wise are Wretched, and Fools only Bless'd.

div.trailer: The End of the Third ACT.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I Heard him loud as I came by the Closet-Door, and my Lady with him, but she seem'd to moderate his Passion.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Ay, Hell thank her, as gentle breezes moderate a fire; but I shall counter-work her Spells, and ride the Witch in her own Bridle.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: It's impossible; she'll cast beyond you still— I'll lay my Life it will never be a Match.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Between you and me.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: My Mind gives me it wont— because we are both so willing; we each of us strive to reach the Gole, and hinder one another in the Race; I swear it never do's well when the Parties are so agreed— for when People walk hand in hand, there's neither overtaking nor meeting: We Hunt in Couples where we both pursue the same Game, but forget one another; and 'tis because we are so near that we don't think of coming together.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Hum, 'gad I believe there's something in't;— Marriage is the Game that we Hunt, and while we think that we only have it in view, I don't see but we have it in our power.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Within reach; for example, give me your hand; why have you look'd through the wrong end of the Perspective all this while; for nothing has been between us but our fears.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p:
I don't know why we should not steal out of the House this moment and Marry one another, without Consideration
or the fear of Repentance. Pox o'Fortune, Portion, Settlements and Joyntures.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Ay, ay, what have we to do with 'em; you know we Marry for Love.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Love, Love, down right very Villanous Love.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: And he that can't live upon Love, deserves to die in a Ditch— Here then, I give you my promise, in spight of Duty, any temptation of Wealth, your inconstancy, or my own inclination to change.—

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: To run most wilfully and unreasonably away with me this moment and be Married.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Hold— Never to Marry any Body elfe.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: That's but a kind of Negative Consent.— Why, you wont baulk the Frollick?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: If you had not been so assured of your own Conduct I would not— But 'tis but reasonable that since I consent to like a Man without the vile Consideration os Money, He should give me a very evident demonstration of his Wit: Therefore let me see you undermine my Lady Touchwood, as you boasted, and force her to give her Consent, and then—

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: And I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: This very next ensuing hour of Eight a Clock, is the last Minute of her Reign, unless the Devil assist her in propria persona.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Well, if the Devil should assist her, and your Plot miscarry.—

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Ay, what am I to trust to then?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Why if you give me very clear demonstration that it was the Devil, I'll allow for irresistable odds. But if I find it to be only chance, or destiny, or unlucky Stars, or any thing but the very Devil, I'm inexorable: Only still I'll keep my word, and live a Maid for your sake.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: And you won't die one, for your own, so still there's hope.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Here's my Mother-in-Law, and your Friend Careless, I would not have'em see us together yet.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: I swear, Mr. Careless, you are very alluring— And say so many fine things, and nothing is so moving to me as a fine thing. Well, I must do you this justice, and declare in the face of the World, never any body gain'd so far upon me as your self, with Blushes I must own it, you have shaken, as I may say, the very foundation of my Honour— Well, sure if I escape your Importunities, I shall value my self as long as I live, I swear.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: And Despise me.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: The last of any Man in the World, by my purity; now you make me swear— O Gratitude for bid, that I should ever be wanting in a respectful acknowledgment of an intire resignation of all my best Wishes, for the Person and Parts of so accomplish'd a Person, whose Merit challenges much more, I'm sure, than my illiterate Praises can description.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Ah Heavens, Madam, you ruine me wirh Kindness; your Charming Tongue pursues the Victory of your Eyes, while at your Feet your poor Adorer dies.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: Ah! Very fine.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Ah why are you so Fair, so bewitching Fair? O let me grow to the ground here, and feast upon that hand; O let me press it to my heart, my aking trembling heart, the nimble movement shall instruct your Pulse, and teach it to allarm Desire.

div.stage: Zoons I'm almost at the end of my Cant, if she does not yield quickly.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: O that's so passionate and fine, I cannot hear it— I am not safe if I stay, and must leave you.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: And must you leave me! Rather let me Languish out a Wretched Life, and breath my Soul beneath your Feet.

div.stage: I must say the same thing over again, and can't help it

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: I swear I am ready to Languish too— O my Honour! Whither is it going? I protest you have given me the Palpitation of the Heart.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Can you be so cruel.—

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: O rise I beseech you, say no more till you rise— Why did you kneel so long? I swear I was so tranported, I did not see it.— Well, to shew you how far you have gain'd upon me; I assure you if Sir Paul should die, of all Mankind there's none I'd sooner make my second choice.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: O Heaven! I can't out-live this Night without your favour— I feel my Spirits faint, a general dampness over spreads my face, a cold deadly dew already vents through all my Pores, and will to Morrow wash me for ever from your sight, and drown me in my Tomb.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: O you have Conquered, sweet, melting, moving Sir, you have Conquered— What heart of Marble can refrain to weep and yield to such sad Sayings.—

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I thank Heav'n, they are the saddest that I ever said— Oh!

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: Oh, I yield my self all up to your uncontroulable Embraces— Say, thou dear dying Man, when, where, and how— Ah, there's Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: 'Slife yonder's Sir Paul, but if he were not come, I'm so transported I cannot speak— This Note will inform you.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Thou art my tender Lambkin, and shalt do what thou wilt— But endeavour to forget this Mellefont.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I would obey you to my power, Sir; but if I have not him, I have sworn never to Marry.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Never to Marry! Heaven forbid; must I neither have Sons nor Grandsons? Must the Family of the Plyants be utterly extinct for want of Issue Male. Oh Impiety! But did you swear, did that sweet Creature swear! ha? How durst you swear without my Consent, ha? Gads-bud, who am I?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Pray don't be angry, Sir, when I swore, I had your Consent; and therefore I swore.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why then the revoking my Consent does annul, or make of none effect your Oath: So you may unswear it again— The Law will allow it.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Ay, but my Conscience never will.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Gads-bud no matter for that, Conscience and Law never go together; you must not expect that.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: Ay, but Sir Paul, I conceive if she has sworn, d'ye mark me, if she has once sworn: It is most unchristian, inhumane, and obscene that she should break it.— I'll make up this Match again, because Mr. Careless said it would oblige him.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Does your Ladiship conceive so— Why I was of that Opinion once too— Nay if your Ladiship conceives so, I'm of that Opinion again; but I can neither find my Lord nor my Lady to know what they intend.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I'm satisfied that my Cousin Mellefont has been much wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I'm amazed to find her of our side, for I'm sure she lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: I know my Lady Touchwood has no kindness for him; and besides, I have been inform'd by Mr. Careless, that Mellefont had never any thing more than a profound respect— That he has own'd himself to be my Admirer 'tis true, but he never was so presumptuous to entertain any dishonourable Notions of things; so that if this be made plain— I don't see how my Daughter can in Conscience, or Honour, or any thing in the World.—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Indeed if this be made plain, as my Lady your Mother says Child—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Plain! I was inform'd of it by Mr. Careless— And I assure you Mr. Careless is a Person— that has a most extraordinary respect and honour for you, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: And for your Ladiship too, I believe, or else you had not chang'd sides so soon; now I begin to find it.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I am much obliged to Mr. Careless really, he is a Person that I have a great value for not only for that, but because he has a great veneration for your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: O las, no indeed, Sir Paul, 'tis upon your account.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: No I protest and vow, I have no title to his esteem, but in having the honour, to appertain in some measure, to your Ladiship, that's all.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: O law now, I swear and declare, it shan't be so, you'r too modest, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: It becomes me, when there is any comparison made, between—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: O fy, fy, Sir Paul, you'l put me out of Countenance— Your very obedient and affectionate Wife; that's all— and highly honoured in that Title.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Gads bud, I am transported! give me leave to kiss your Ladiships Hand.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: That my poor Father, should be so very silly.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My Lip indeed, Sir Paul, I swear you shall.

div.stage: He kisses her, and bows very low.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Ladiship— I don't know whether I fly on Ground, or walk in Air— Gads bud, she was never thus before— Well, I must own my self the most beholden to Mr. Careless— As sure as can be this is all his doings— something that he has said; Well, 'tis a rare thing to have an ingenious Friend. Well, your Ladiship is of opinion that the Match may go forward.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: By all means— Mr. Careless has satisfied me of the matter.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Well, why then Lamb you may keep your Oath, but have a care of making rash Vows; Come hither to me, kiss and Papa.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I swear and declare, I am such a twitter to read Mr. Careless his Letter, that I can't forbear any longer— but though I may read all Letters first by Prerogative, yet I'll be sure to be unsuspected this time.— Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Did your Ladiship call?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Nay, not to interrupt you my Dear— only lend me your Letter, which you had from your Steward to day: I would look upon the Account again; and may be increase your Allowance.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: There it is, Madam; Do you want a Pen and Ink?

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: No, no, nothing else I thank you, Sir Paul,— So now I can read my own Letter under the cover of his.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: He? And wilt thou bring a Grandson at 9 Months end— He? A brave Chopping Boy.— I'll settle a Thousand pound a Year upon the Rogue as soon as ever he looks me in the Face, I will Gads-bud. I'm overjoy'd to think I have any of my Family that will bring Children into the World. For I would fain have some resemblance of my self in my Posterity, he Thy? Can't you contrive that affair Girl? Do gads-bud, think on thy old Father; Heh? Make the young Rogue as like as you can.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I'm glad to see you so merry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Merry, Gads-bud I'm serious, I'll give thee 500 l. for every inch of him that resembles me; ah this Eye, this Left Eye! A 1000 l. for this Left Eye. This has done Execution in its time Girl; why thou hast my Leer Hussey, just thy Father's Leer.— Let it be transmitted to the young Rogue by the help of imagination; why, 'tis the mark of our Family Thy; our House is distinguished by a Languishing Eye, as the House of Austria is by a thick Lip.— Ah! when I was of your Age Hussy, I would have held sifty to one, I could have drawn'my own Picture— Gads-bud I could have done— not so much as you neither,— but— Nay, don't Blush—

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I don't Blush Sir, for I vow I don't understand.—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Pshaw, Pshaw, you fib you Baggage, you do understand, and you shall understand, come don't be so nice, Gads-bud don't learn after your Mother-in-Law my Lady here: Marry Heaven forbid that you should follow her Example, that would spoil all indeed. Bless us, if you should take a Vagarie and make a rash Resolution on your Wedding Night, to die a Maid; as she did. All were ruin'd, all my hopes lost— My Heart would break, and my Estate would be left to the wide World, he? I hope you are a better Christian than to think of being a Nun; he? Answer me?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I'm all Obedience, Sir, to your Commands.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: O dear Mr. Careless, I swear he writes charmingly, and he talks charmingly, and he looks charmingly, and he has charm'd me, as much as I have charm'd him; and so I'll tell him in the Wardrobe when 'tis Dark. O Crimine! I hope, Sir Paul has not seen both Letters. Sir Paul, here's your Letter, to Morrow Morning I'll settle the Accounts to your Advantage.

div.stage: Puts the wrong Letter hastily up, and gives him her own.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Sir Paul, Gads-bud you're an uncivil Person, let me tell you, and all that; and I did not think it had been in you.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: O Law, what's the matter now? I hope you are not angry, Mr. Brisk.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Deuce take me I believe you intend to Marry your Daughter your self; you're always brooding over her like an Old Hen, as if she were not well hatch'd, I'gad, he?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Good strange! Mr. Brisk is such a Merry Facetious Person, he, he, he. No, no, I have done with her. I have done with her now.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: The Fiddles have stay'd this hour in the Hall, and my Lord Froth wants a Partner, we can never begin without her.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Go, go Child, go, get you gone and Dance and be Merry, I'll come and look at you by and by.— Where's my Son Mellefont?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I'll send him to them, I know where he is—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Sir Paul, will you send Careless into the Hall if you meet him.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I will, I will, I'll go and look for him on purpose.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
So now they are all gone, and I have an opportunity to practice.— Ah! My dear Lady Froth! She's a most
engaging Creature, if she were not so fond of that damn'd coxcomly Lord of hers; and yet I am forced to allow him Wit too, to keep in with him— No matter, she's a Woman of parts, and I'gad parts will carry her. She said she would follow me into the Gallery— Now to make my Approaches— Hem hem! Ah Madam!— Pox on't, why should I disparage my parts by thinking what to say? None but dull Rogues think; witty Men like rich Fellows, are always ready for all Expences; while your Blockheads, like poor needy Scoundrels, are forced to examine their Stock, and forecast the Charges of the Day. Here she comes, I'll seem not to see her, and try to win her with a new airy invention of my own, hem!
sp.l: I'm sick with Love, ha ha ha, prithee come walking about.. Cure me.
I'm sick with, &c.
sp.p: O ye Powers! O my Lady Froth, my Lady Froth! My Lady Froth! Heigho! Break Heart; God's I thank you.

div.stage: Stands musing with his Arms a-cross.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: O Heavens Mr. Brisk! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: My Lady Froth! Your Ladyships most humble Servant;—— The matter Madam? Nothing, Madam, nothing at all I'gad. I was fallen into the most agreeable amusement in the whole Province of Contemplation: That's all— (I'll seem to conceal my Passion, and that will look like Respect.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr,
sp.p: Bless me, why did you call out upon me so loud?—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: O Lord I Madam! I beseech your Ladiship— when?

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: Just now as I came in, bless me, why don't you know it?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Not I, let me perish— But did I! Strange! I confess your Ladiship was in my Thoughts; and I was in
a sort of Dream that did in a manner represent a very pleasing Object to my imagination, but— But did I indeed?— To see how Love and Murder will out. But did I really name my Lady Froth?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Three times aloud, as I love Letters— But did you talk of Love? O Parnassus! Who would have thought Mr. Brisk could have been in Love, ha ha ha. O Heaven's I thought you cou'd have no Mistress but the Nine Muses.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: No more I have I'gad, for I adore 'em all in your Ladiship— Let me perish, I don't know whether to be splenatick, or airy upon't; the Deuce take me if I can tell whether I am glad or sorry that your Ladiship has made the Discovery.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: O be merry by all means— Prince Voscius in Love! Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: O barbarous, to turn me into ridicule! Yet, ha ha ha. The Deuce take me, I can't help laughing my self neither, ha ha ha; yet by Heavens I have violent passion for your Ladiship, seriously.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: Seriously? Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Seriously, ha ha ha. Gad I have, for all I Laugh.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: Ha ha ha! What d'e think I Laugh at? Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Me I'gad, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: No the Deuce take me if I don't Laugh at my self; for hang me if I have not a violent Passion for Mr. Brisk, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Seriously?

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: Seriously, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: That's well enough; let me perish, ha ha ha. O Miraculous, what a happy Discovery. Ah my dear charming Lady Froth!

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: Oh my adored Mr. Brisk!

sp.speaker: Lord Fr.
sp.p: The Company are all ready— How now!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Zoons, Madam, there's my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: Take no notice— But observe me— Now cast off, and meet me at the lower end of the Room, and then joyn hands again; I could teach my Lord this Dance purely, but I vow Mr. Brisk, I can't tell how to come so near any other Man. Oh here's my Lord, now you shall see me do it with him.

div.stage: They pretend to practice part of a Country-Dance.

sp.speaker: Ld Fr.
sp.p: — Oh I see there's no harm yet— But I don't like this familiarity.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: — Shall you and I do our close Dance to show Mr. Brisk?

sp.speaker: Ld Fr.
sp.p: — No, my Dear, do it with him.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: — I'll do it with him, my Lord, when you are out of the way.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: That's good I'gad, that's good, Deuce take me I can hardly hold Laughing in his Face.

sp.speaker: Ld Fr.
sp.p: Any other time, my Dear, or we'll Dance it below.

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Come my Lord, I'll wait on you— My charming witty Angel!

sp.speaker: Lady Fr.
sp.p: We shall have whispering time enough, you know, since we are Partners.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: O Mr. Careless, Mr. Careless, I'm ruin'd, I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: What's the matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: O the unlucki'st Accident, I'm afraid I shan't live to tell it you.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid! What is it?

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: I'm in such a fright; the strangest Quandary and Premunire! I'm all over in a Universal Agitation, I dare swear every Circumstance of me trembles.— O your Letter, your Letter! By an Unfortunate Mistake, I have given Sir Paul your Letter instead of his own.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: That was unlucky.—

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: O yonder he comes reading of it, for Heavens sake step in here and advise me quickly, before he sees.

div.stage: Enter Sir Paul with the Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: — O Providence, what a Conspiracy have I discover'd— But let me see to make an end on't.—

Hum— After Supper in the Wardrobe by the Gallery. If Sir Paul should surprize us, I have a Commission from him to treat with you about the very matter of Fact.— Matter of Fact! Very pretty; it seems then I am conducing to my own Cuckoldom; why this is the very traiterous Position of taking up Arms by my Authority, against my Person! Well, let me see— Till then I languish in expectation of my Adored Charmer.

Gads bud, would that were Matter of Fact too. Die and be Damn'd for a Iudas Maccabeus, and Iscariot both. O friendship! What art thou but a Name! Henceforward, let no Man make a Friend that would not be a Cuckold: For whomsoever he receives into his bosom, will find the way to his Bed, and there return his Caresses with interest to his Wife. Have I for this been pinion'd Night after Night for three Years past? Have I been swath'd in Blankets till I have even been depriv'd of motion, and render'd uncapable of using the common benefits of Nature? Have I approach'd the Marriage Bed with reverence as to a sacred shrine, and deny'd my self the enjoyment of lawful Domestick Pleasures to preserve its Purity, and must I now find it polluted
by Foreign Iniquity? O my Lady Plyant, you were Chaste as Ice, but you are melted now, and false as Water.— But Providence has been constant to me in discovering this Conspiracy; still I am beholden to Providence, if it were not for Providence, sure poor Sir Paul thy Heart would break.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: So Sir, I see you have read the Letter;— well now, Sir Paul, what do you think of your Friend Careless? Has he been Treacherous, or did you give his insolence a License to make trial of your Wifes suspected Vertue? De è see here? Look, read it? Gad's my Life if I thought it were so, I would this moment renounce all Communication with you. Ungrateful Monster! He? Is it so? Ay, I see it, a Plot upon my Honour; your guilty Cheeks confess it; Oh where shall wrong'd Vertue fly for Reparation! I'll be Divorced this instant.

div.stage: Snatches the Letter as in anger.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Gads-bud, what shall I say? This is the strangest Surprize! Why I don't know any thing at all, nor I don't know whether there be any thing at all in the World, or no.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I thought I should try you, false Man. I that never dissembled in my Life Yet to make tryal of you, pretended to like that Monster of Iniquity, Careless, and found out that contrivance to let you see this Letter; which now I find was of your own inditing— I do Heathen, I do, see my Face no more; there has hardly been Consummation between us, and I'll be Divorced presently.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: O strange, what will become of me!— I'm so amazed, and so overjoy'd, so afraid, and so sorry.— But did you give me this Letter on purpose he? Did you?

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: Did I? Do you doubt me, Turk, Sarazen? I have a Cousin that's a Proctor in the Commons, I'll go to him instantly.—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Hold, stay, I beseech your Ladiship— I'm so overjoy'd, stay I'll confess all.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: What will you confess, Jew?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Why now as I hope to be saved, I had no hand in this Letter— Nay hear me, I beseech your Ladiship: The Devil take me now if he did not go beyond my Commission— If I desired him to do any more than speak a good word only just for me, Gads-bud only for poor Sir Paul, I'm an Anabaptist, or a Jew, or what you please to call me.

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: Why is not here Matter of Fact?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Ay, but by your own Vertue and Continency that matter of Fact is all his own doing.— I confess I had a great desire to have some Honours Conferr'd upon me, which lie all in your Ladiships Breast, and he being a well spoken Man, I desired him to intercede for me.—

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: Did you so, Presumption! Well, remember for this, your Right Hand shall be swathed down again to Night— and I thought to have always allow'd you that Liberty—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Nay but Madam, I shall offend again if you don't allow me that to reach—

sp.speaker: Lady Pl.
sp.p: Drink the less you Sot, and do't before you come to Bed.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Sir Paul, I'm glad I've met with you, 'gad I have said all I could, but can't prevail— Then my Friendship to you has carried me a little farther in this matter—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Indeed— Well Sir— I'll dissemble with him a little.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p:
Why faith I have in my time known Honest Gentlemen abused by a pretended Coyness in their Wives, and I had a mind to try my Ladies Vertue— And when I could not prevail for you, 'gad I pretended to be in Love my self— but all in vain, she would not hear a word upon that
Subject: Then I writ a Letter to her; I don't know what effects that will have, but I'll be sure to tell you when I do, tho' by this Light I believe her Virtue is impregnable.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: O Providence! Providence! What Discoveries are here made? Why, this is better and more Miraculous than the rest.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I can't tell you I'm so overjoy'd; come along with me to my Lady, I can't contain my self; come my dear Friend.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: So, so, so, this difficulty's over.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Maskwell! I have been looking for you— 'tis within a Quarter of Eight.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: My Lady is just gone down from my Lords Closet, you had best steal into her Chamber before she comes, and lie conceal'd there; otherwise she may Lock the Door when we are together, and you not easily get in to surprize us.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: He? you say true.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You had best make haste, for she's but gone to make some Apology to the Company for her own, and my Lords absence all this while, and will to her Chamber instantly.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: I go this moment: Now Fortune I defie thee.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I confess you may be allow'd to be secure in your own Opinion; the appearance is very fair, but I have an After-Gamé to play that shall turn the Tables, and here comes the Man that I must Manage.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Maskwell, you are the Man I wish'd to meet.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am happy to be in the way of your Lordships Commands.

sp.speaker: Ld T.
sp.p: I have always found you prudent and careful in any thing that has concern'd me or my Family.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I were a Villain else— I am bound by Duty and Gratitude, and my own Inclination, to be ever your Lordship's Servant.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Enough— You are my Friend; I know it: Yet there has been a thing in your Knowledge, which has concern'd me nearly, that you have conceal'd from me.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Nay, I excuse your Friendship to my unnatural Nephew thus far— but I know you have been Privy to his impious Designs upon my Wife. This Evening she has told me all: Her good Nature conceal'd it as long as was possible; but he perseveres so in Villany, that she has told me even you were weary of disswading him, though you have once actually hindered him from forcing her.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am sorry, my Lord, I can make you no Answer; this is an Occasion in which I would not willingly be so silent.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I know you would excuse him— and I know as well that you can't.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Indeed I was in hopes 'thad been a youthful Heat that might have soon boil'd over; but—

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: Say on.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I have nothing more to say, my Lord— but to express my Concern; for I think his Frenzy increases daily.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: How! give me but Proof of it, Ocular Proof, that I may justifie my Dealing with him to the World, and share my Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: O my Lord! consider that is hard: besides, time may work upon him: then, for me to do it! I have profess'd an everlasting Friendship to him.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: He is your Friend, and what am I?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am answered.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p:
Fear not his Displeasure; I will put you out of his, and Fortune's Power, and for that thou art scrupulously honest, I will secure thy Fidelity to him, and give my Honour
never to own any Discovery that you shall make me. Can you give me a demonstrative Proof? Speak.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I wish I could not— To be plain, my Lord, I intended this Evening to have try'd all Arguments to disswade him from a Design, which I suspect; and if I had not succeeded, to have informed your Lordship of what I knew.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I thank you. What is the Villains Purpose?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: He has own'd nothing to me of late, and what I mean now, is only a bare Suspicion of my own. If your Lordship will meet me a quarter of an Hour hence there, in that Lobby by my Lady's Bed-Chamber, I shall be able to tell you more.

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: My Duty to your Lordship, makes me do a severe Piece of Justice—

sp.speaker: Ld. T.
sp.p: I will be secret, and reward your Honesty beyond your Hopes.

div.stage: SCENE opening, shews Lady Touchwood's Chamber. Mellefont, Solus.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Pray Heaven my Aunt keep touch with her Assignation— Oh that her Lord were but sweating behind this Hanging, with the Expectation of what I shall see— Hist, she comes— Little does she think what a Mine is just ready to spring under her Feet. But to my Post.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: 'Tis Eight a Clock: Methinks I should have found him here. Who does not prevent the Hour of Love; outstays the Time; for to be dully punctual, is too slow.— I was accusing you of Neglect.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I confess you do Reproach me when I see you here before me; but 'tis fit I should be still behind hand, still to be more and more indebted to your goodness.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: You can excuse a fault too well, not to have been too blame— a ready Answer shews you were prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Guilt is ever at a loss and confusion waits upon it, when Innocence and bold Truth are always ready for expression——

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Not in Love, Words are the weak support of Cold indifference; Love has no Language to be heard.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Excess of Joy had made me stupid! Thus may my Lips be ever clos'd.
And thus▪— Oh who would not lose his Speech, upon condition to have Joys above it?

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Hold, let me Lock the Door first.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: That I believ'd; 'twas well I left the private passage open.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: So, that's safe.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: And so may all your Pleasures be, and secret as this kiss—

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: And may all Treachery be thus discovered.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Villain!

sp.speaker: Mask
sp.p: Nay then, there's but one way.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Say you so, were you provided for an Escape? Hold, Madam, you have no more holes to your Burrough, I'll stand between you and this Sally-Port.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Thunder strike thee Dead for this Deceit, immediate Lightning blast thee, me and the whole World— Oh! I could rack my self, play the Vulture to my own Heart, and gnaw it piece-meal, for not boding to me this misfortune.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Be Patient.—

sp.speaker: Lady. T.
sp.p: Be Damn'd.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Consider I have you on the hook; you will but flounder your self a weary, and be nevertheless my Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Lady. T.
sp.p: I'le hold my breath and die, but I'le be free.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: O Madam, have a care of dying unprepared, I doubt you have some unrepented Sins that may hang heavy and retard your flight.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: O. What shall I do? say? whither shall I turn? has Hell no remedy?

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: None, Hell has served you even as Heaven has done, left you to your self.— You're in a kind of Erasmus Paradice; yet if you please you may make it a Purgatory; and with a little Pennance and my Absolution all this may turn to good account.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Hold in my passion, and fall, fall, a little thou swelling Heart; let me have some intermission of this rage, and one minutes coolness to dissemble.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: You have been to blame.— I like those Tears, and hope they are of the purest kind— Penitential Tears.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: O the Scene was shifted quick before me— I had not time to think— I was surprised to see a Monster in the Glass, and now I find it is my self; Can you have mercy to forgive the faults I have imagined, but never put in practice— O Consider, Consider, how fatal you have been to me, you have already killed the quiet of this Life, the love of you, was the first wandring fire that e're misled my steps, and while I had only that in view, I ways betray'd into unthought of ways of ruine.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: May I believe this true?

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: O be not cruelly incredulous— How can you doubt these streaming Eyes? Keep the severest Eye o're all my future Conduct; and if I once relapse, let me not hope forgiveness, 'twill ever be in your power to ruin me— My Lord shall sign to your desires; I will my self create your Happiness, and Cynthia shall be this night your Bride— Do but conceal my failings, and forgive—

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Upon such terms I will be ever yours in every honest way.

div.stage: Enter Lord Touchwood, Maskwell softly behind him.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I have kept my word, he's here, but I must not be seen.

sp.speaker: Lord T.
sp.p: Hell and Amazement, she's in Tears.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Eternal Blessings thank you— Ha! my Lord listning! O Fortune has o'repaid me all, all! all's my own!

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech you rise.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Never, never! I'le grow to the Ground, be buried quick beneath it, e're I be consenting to so damn'd a Sin as Incest! unnatural Incest!

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: O cruel Man, will you not let me go— I'le forgive all that's past— O Heaven, you will not ravish me!

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Lord T.
sp.p: Monster, Dog! your Life shall answer this—

div.stage: Draws, and runs at Mell. is held by Lady Touch.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: O Heavens my Lord! hold, hold, for Heavens sake.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Confusion, my Uncle! O the damn'd Sorceress.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Moderate your rage good my Lord! he's mad, alas he's mad— indeed he's my Lord, and knows not what he does— see how wild he looks.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: By Heaven'twere senceless not to be mad, and see such Witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: My Lord, you hear him— he talks Idly.

sp.speaker: Lord T.
sp.p: Hence from my sight, thou living infamy to my Name; when next I see that Face, I'le write Villain in't with my Swords point.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p:
Now, by my Soul, I will not go till I have made known my wrongs— Nay, till I have made known yours, which (if possible) are greater— Though she has all the Host of Hell her Servants; Though she can wear more shapes in
shining day, then fear shews Cowards in the dark——

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Alas he raves! talks very Poetry! for Heavens sake away my Lord, he'l either tempt you to extravagance, or commit some himself.

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Death and Funes, will you not hear me— Why by Heaven she laughs, grins, points to your Back, she forks out Cuckoldom with her Fingers, and you're running Horn mad after your Fortune.

div.stage: As she is going she turns back and smiles at him.

sp.speaker: Lord T.
sp.p: I fear he's mad indeed-Let's send Maskwell to him-

sp.speaker: Melle.
sp.p: Send him, to her.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: Come, come, good my Lord, my Heart akes so, I shall faint if I stay.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: O I could curse my Stars, Fate, and Chance; all Causes and Accidents of Fortune in this Life! but to what purpose? yet, 'sdeath, for a Man to have the fruit of all his Industry grown full and ripe, ready to drop into his mouth, and just when he holds out his hand to gather it, to have a sudden Whirlwind come, tear up Tree and all, and bear away the very root and foundation of his hopes; What temper can contain? They talk of sending Miskwell to me; I never had more need of him— But what can he do? Imagination cannot form a fairer and more plausible design than this of his which has miscarried.— O my Pretious Aunt, I shall never thrive without I deal with the Devil, or another Woman.
sp.l: Women like flames have a destroying pow'r,
Ne'er to be quench'd, till they themselves devour.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: WAst not Lucky?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Lucky! Fortune is your own, and 'tis her interest so to be; By Heaven I believe you can controul her power, and she fears it; though chance brought my Lord, 'twas your own art that turned it to advantage.

sp.speaker: Lady T.
sp.p: 'Tis true it might have been my ruine— but yonder's my Lord, I believe he's coming to find you, I'le not be seen.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: So; I durst not own my introducing my Lord, though it succeeded well for her, for she would have suspected a design which I should have been puzled to excuse. My Lord is thoughtful— I'le be so too; yet he shall know my thoughts; or think he does—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Lord T.
sp.p: Talking to himself!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: 'Twas honest— And shall I be rewarded for it? No, 'twas honest, therefore I shan't;— Nay, rather, therefore I ought not; for it rewards it self.

sp.speaker: Lord T.
sp.p: Unequall'd Virtue!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: But should it be known! then I have lost a Friend! He was an ill Man, and I have gain'd; for half my self I lent him, and that, I have recall'd; so I have served my self, and what is yet better, I have served a worthy Lord to whom I owe my self.

sp.speaker: Lord T.
sp.p: Excellent Man!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Yet I am wretched— O there is a secret burns within this Breast, which should it once blaze forth, would ruine all, consume my honest Character, and brand me with the name of Villain.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Why do I love! yet Heaven and my waking Conscience are my Witnesses, I never gave one working thought a vent; which might discover that I lov'd, nor ever must; no, let it prey upon my Heart; for I would rather die, than seem once, barely seem, dishones:— O, should it once be known I love fair Cynthia, all this. that I have done, would look like Rivals Malice, false Friendship to my Lord, and base Self-interest. Let me perish first, and from this hour avoid all sight and speech, and, if I can, all thought of that pernicious Beauty. Ha! but what is my distraction doing? I am wildly talking to my self, and some ill Chance might have directed malicious Ears this way.

div.stage: Seems to start, seeing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Start not— let guilty and dishonest Souls start at the revelation of their thoughts, but be thou fix'd, as is thy Vertue.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am confounded, and beg your Lordship's pardon for those free discourses which I have had with my self.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Come, I beg your pardon that I over-heard you, and yet it shall not need— Honest Maskwell! thy and my good Genius led me hither— mine, in that I have discovered so much Manly Vertue; thine, in that thou shalt have due reward of all thy worth. Give me thy hand— my Nephew is the alone remaining Branch of all our ancient Family; him I thus blow away, and constitute thee in his room to be my Heir—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Now Heaven forbid—

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: No more— I have resolv'd— The Writings are ready drawn, and wanted nothing but to be sign'd, and have his name inserted— yours will fill the Blank as well— I will have no reply— Let me command this time; for 'tis the last, in which I will assume Authority— hereafter, you shall rule where I have Power.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I humbly would petition—

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Is't for your self?—
I'll hear of nought for any body else.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Then witness Heaven for me, this Wealth and Honour was not of my seeking, nor would I build my Fortune on another's ruine: I had but one desire—

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Thou shalt enjoy it— if all I'm worth in Wealth or Interest can purchase Cynthia, she is thine.— I'm sure Sir Paul's Consent will follow Fortune; I'll quickly show him which way that is going.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You oppress me with Bounty; my Gratitude is weak, and shrinks beneath the weight, and cannot rise to thank you— What, enjoy my Love! Forgive the Transports of a Blessing so unexpected, so unhop'd for, so unthought of!

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: I will confirm it, and rejoyce with thee.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: This is prosperous indeed— Why let him find me out a Villain, settled in possession of a fair Estate, and full fruition of my Love, I'll bear the railings of a losing Gamester— but shou'd he find me out before! 'tis dangerous to delay— let me think— shou'd my Lord proceed to treat openly of my Marriage with Cynthia, all must be discover'd, and Mellefont can be no longer blinded.— It must not be; nay, shou'd my Lady know it— ay, then were fine work indeed! her fury wou'd spare nothing, tho' she involv'd her self in ruine. No, it must be by Stratagem— I must deceive Mellefont once more, and get my Lord to consent to my private management. He comes opportunely— now will I, in my old way, discover the whole and real truth of the matter to him, that he may not suspect one word on't.
sp.l: No Mask like open Truth to cover Lies,
As to go naked is the best disguise.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
O Maskwell, what hopes? I am confounded in a maze of thoughts, each leading into one another, and all ending
in perplexity. My Uncle will not see, nor hear me.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No matter, Sir, don't trouble your head, all's in my power.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: How? for Heaven's sake?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Little do you think that your Aunt has kept her word,— how the Devil she wrought my Lord into this dotage, I know not; but he's gone to Sir Paul about my Marriage with Cynthia, and has appointed me his Heir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: The Devil he has! what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I have it, it must be by Stratagem; for it's in vain to make Application to him. I think I have that in my head that cannot fail: Where's Cynthia?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: In the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Let us go and consult her, my life for yours, I cheat my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Maskwell your Heir, and Marry Cynthia!

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: I cannot do too much, for so much merit.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: But this is a thing of too great moment, to be so suddenly resolv'd. Why, Cynthia? Why must he be Married? Is there not reward enough in raising his low Fortune, but he must mix his Blood with mine, and Wed my Niece? how know you that my Brother will consent, or she? nay, he himself perhaps may have Affections otherwhere.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: No, I am convinced he loves her.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Maskwell love Cynthia, impossible!

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: I told you, he confess'd it to me.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Confusion! how's this!

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: His humility long stifled his Passion: And his Love of Mellefont would have made him still conceal it,— but, by Encouragement, I wrung the secret from him; and know he's no way to be rewarded but in her. I'll defer my farther proceedings in it, till you have consider'd it, but remember how we are both indebted to him.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p:
Both indebted to him! yes, we are both indebted to him, if you knew all, damn'd Villain! oh, I am
wild with this surprize of Treachery: Hell and Fire, it is impossible, it cannot be,— he Love Cynthia! what have I been Bawd to his designs? his Property only, a baiting place to stay his stomach in the road to her; now I see what made him false to Mellefont,— Shame and Destruction! I cannot bear it, oh! what Woman can bear to be a Property? To be kindled to a flame, only to light him to anothers Arms; oh! that I were Fire indeed, that I might burn the vile Traytor to a Hell of Torments,— but he's Damnation proof, a Devil already, and Fire is his Element. What shall I do? how shall I think? I cannot think,— all my designs are lost, my Love unsated, my Revenge unfinished, and fresh cause of fury from unthought of Plagues.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Madam, Sister, my Lady Sister, did you see my Lady my Wife?

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Oh! Torture!

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Gad'sbud, I can't find her high nor low; where can she be, think you?

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Where she's serving you, as all your Sex ought to be served; making you a Beast. Don't you know that you're a Fool, Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: A Fool; he, he, he, you're merry— no, no, not I, I know no such matter.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Why then you don't know half your happyness?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: That's a jest with all my heart, faith and troth,— but hearkee, my Lord told me something of a Revolution of things; I don't know what to make on't,— gad'sbud I must consult my Wife,— he talks of disinheriting his Nephew; and I don't know what,— look you, Sister, I must know what my Girl has to trust to; or not a syllable of a Wedding, gad'sbud— to shew you that I am not a Fool.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p:
Hear me; consent to the breaking off this Marriage, and the promoting any other, without consulting me,
and I'll renounce all Blood, all relation and concern with you for ever,— nay, I'll be your Enemy, and pursue you to Destruction, I'll tear your Eyes out, and tread you under my feet.—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter now? Good Lord, what's all this for? Pooh, here's a joke, indeed— why, where's my Wife?

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: With Careless, in the close Arbour, he may want you by this time, as much as you want her.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: O, if she be with Mr. Careless, 'tis well enough.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Fool, Sot, insensible Ox! but remember what I said to you, or you had better eat your own Horns, and Pimp for your living; by this light you had.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: She's a passionate Woman, gad'sbud,— but to say truth, all our Family are Cholerick; I am the only peaceable Person amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I know no other way but this he has proposed; If you have Love enough to run the venture.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I don't know whether I have Love enough,— but I find I have obstinacy enough to pursue whatever I have once resolved; and a true Female courage to oppose any thing that resists my will, tho' 'twere reason it self.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: That's right,— well, I'll secure the Writings; and run the hazard along with you.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: But how can the Coach and six Horses be got ready without suspicion?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Leave it to my care; that shall be so far from being suspected, that it shall be got ready by my Lord's own order.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Why, I intend to tell my Lord the whole matter of our Contrivance, that's my way.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p:
Why, I'll tell my Lord, I laid this Plot with you, on purpose to betray you; and that which put me upon it,
was, the finding it impossible to gain the Lady any other way, but in the hopes of her Marrying you.—

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: So.—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: So, why so, while you are busied in making your self ready, I'll wheedle her into the Coach; and instead of you, Borrow my Lords Chaplain, and so run away with her my self.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: O I conceive you, you'll tell him so?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Tell him so! Ay, why you don't think I mean to do so?

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: No, no; ha, ha, I dare swear thou wilt not.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You may be deceiv'd— Therefore, for our farther Security, I would have you Disguis'd like a Parson, that if my Lord should have Curiosity to peep, he may not discover you in the Coach, but think the Cheat is carried on as he would have it.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Excellent Maskwell, thou wer't certainly meant for a Statesman or a Jesuite, but that thou'rt too honest for one, and too pious for the other.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Well, get your selves ready, and meet me in half an hour, yonder in my Lady's Dressing-Room; go by the back Stairs, and so we may slip down without being observ'd.— I'll send the Chaplain to you with his Robes; I have made him my own,— and ordered him to meet us to Morrow Morning at St. Albans; there we will Sum up this Account, to all our satisfactions.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.p: Should I begin to thank or praise thee, I should waste the little time we have.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Madam you will be ready?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I will be punctual to the Minute.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Stay, I have a doubt— upon second thoughts, we had better meet in the Chaplain's Chamber, here the corner Chamber at this end of the Gallery, there is a back way into it, so that you need not come thro' this Door— and a Pair of private Stairs leads down to the Stables— it will be more convenient.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I am guided by you,— but Mellefont will mistake.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No, no, I'll after him immediately, and tell him.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I will not fail.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Why, qui vult decipi decipiatur.— 'Tis no fault of mine, I have told 'em in plain terms, how easie 'tis for me to cheat 'em; and if they will not hear the Serpent's hiss, they must be stung into experience, and future caution,— Now to prepare my Lord to consent to this.— But first I must instruct my little Levite, there is no Plot, publick or private, that can expect to prosper without one of 'em have a finger in't, he promised me to be within at this hour,— Mr. Saygrace, Mr. Saygrace.

div.stage: Goes to the Chamber Door and knocks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Saygrace,
sp.p: Sweet Sir, I will but pen the last Line of an Acrostick, and be with you in the twinckling of an Ejaculation, in the pronouncing of an Amen, or before you can—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Nay, good Mr. Saygrace do not prolong the time, by describing to me the shortness of your stay; rather if you please, defer the finishing of your Wit, and let us talk about our business, it shall be Tithes in your way.

sp.speaker: Saygrace
sp.p: You shall prevail, I would break off in the middle of a Sermon to do you pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You could not do me a greater,— except— the business in hand— have you provided a Habit for Mellefont?

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: I have, they are ready in my Chamber, together with a clean starch'd Band and Cuffs.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Good, let them be carried to him,— have you stitch'd the Gown Sleeve, that he may be puzzled, and waste time in putting it on?

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: I have; the Gown will not be indued without perplexity.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Meet me in half an Hour, here in your own Chamber. When Cynthia comes, let there be no Light, and do not speak, that she may not distinguish you from Mellefont. I'll urge haste, to excuse your silence.

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: You have no more Commands?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: None, your Text is short.

sp.speaker: Sayg.
sp.p: But pithy, and I will handle it with Discretion.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: It will be the first you have so serv'd.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Sure I was born to be controuled by those I should Command: my very Slaves will shortly give me Rules how I shall govern them.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I am concern'd to see your Lordship discomposed—

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Have you seen my Wife lately, or disobliged her?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No, my Lord. What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Then Mellefont has urg'd some body to incense her— something she has heard of you which carries her beyond the bounds of Patience.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: This I fear'd.
Did not your Lordship tell her of the Honours you designed me?

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: 'Tis that; you know my Lady has a high Spirit, she thinks I am unworthy.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Unworthy! 'tis an ignorant Pride in her to think so— Honesty to me is true Nobility. However, 'tis my Will it should be so, and that shou'd be convincing to her as much as reason— by Heav'n, I'll not be Wife-ridden; were it possible it shou'd be done this night.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: By Heav'n, he meets my wishes
Few things are impossible to willing minds.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Instruct me how this may be done, you shall see I want no inclination.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I had laid a small design for to morrow (as Love will be inventing) which I thought to communicate to your Lordship— but it may be as well done to night.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Here's Company— come this way and tell me.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Is not that he, now gone out with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: By Heaven there's Treachery— the Confusion that I saw your Father in, my Lady Touchwood's Passion, with what imperfectly I over-heard between my Lord and her, confirm me in my fears. Where's Mellefont?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Here he comes.
Did Maskwell tell you any thing of the Chaplain's Chamber?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No; my Dear, will you get ready— the things are all in my Chamber; I want nothing but the Habit.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You are betray'd, and Maskwell is the Villain that I always thought him.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: When you were gone, he said his mind was chang'd, and bid me meet him in the Chaplain's Room, pretending immediately to follow you, and give you notice.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: There's Saygrace tripping by with a bundle under his Arm— he cannot be ignorant that Maskwell means to use his Chamber; let's follow and examine him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: 'Tis loss of time— I cannot think him false.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Lord musing!

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: He has a quick invention, if this were suddenly design'd— yet he says he had prepar'd my Chaplain already.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: How's this! now I fear indeed.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Cynthia here; alone, fair Cousin, and melancholly?

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Your Lordship was thoughtful.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: My thoughts were on serious business, not worth your hearing.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Mine were on Treachery concerning you, and may be worth your hearing.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Treachery concerning me! pray be plain— hark! what noise!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Will you not hear me?

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: No, Monster! Hellish Traitor! no.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Lady and Maskwell! this may be lucky— My Lord, let me entreat you to stand behind this Skreen, and listen; perhaps this chance may give you proof of what you ne're could have believ'd from my suspicions.

div.stage: Enter Lady Touchwood with a Dagger, Maskwell.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: You want but leasure to invent fresh falshood, and sooth me to a fond belief of all your fictions; but I will stab the Lie that's forming in your heart, and save a Sin, in pity to your Soul.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Strike then— Since you will have it so.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Ha! a steady Villain to the last!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Come, why do you dally with me thus?

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Thy stubborn temper shocks me, and you knew it would— by Heav'n, this is Cunning all, and not Courage; no, I know thee well: but thou shalt miss thy aim.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Had do you mock my Rage? then this shall punish your fond, rash Contempt! Again smile.
And such a smile as speaks in Ambiguity!
Ten thousand meanings lurk in each corner of that various face,
O! that they were written in thy heart,
That I, with this, might lay thee open to my sight!
But then 'twill be too late to know—

Thou hast, thou hast found the only way to turn my Rage; Too well thou know'st my jealous Soul cou'd never bear Uncertainty. Speak then, and tell me— yet are you silent? Oh, I am wilder'd in all Passions! but thus my Anger melts.
Here, take this Ponyard, for my very Spirits faint, and I want strength to hold it, thou hast disarm'd my Soul.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Amazement shakes me— where will this end?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: So, 'tis well— let your wild fury have a vent; and when you have temper, tell me.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Now, now, now I am calm, and can hear you.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Thanks, my invention; and now I have it for you.— First tell me what urg'd you to this violence? for your Passion broke in such imperfect terms, that yet I am to learn the cause.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: My Lord himself surpriz'd me with the News, You were to marry Cynthia— that you had own'd your Love to him, and his indulgence would assist you to attain your ends.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: How, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Pray forbear all Resentments for a while, and let us hear the rest

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I grant you in appearance all is true; I seem'd consenting to my Lord; nay, transported with the Blessing— but could you think that I who had been happy in your lov'd Embraces, could e're be sond of an inferiour Slavery.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Ha! O poison to my Ears! what do I hear!

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord, forbear Resentment, let us hear it out.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Yes, I will contain, tho' I cou'd burst.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I that had wanton'd in the wide Circle of your World of Love, cou'd be confin'd within the puny Province of a Girl. No— yet tho' I doat on each last Favour more than all the rest; though I would give a Limb for every look you cheaply throw away on any other Object of your Love; yet so far I prize your Pleasures o're my own, that all this seeming Plot that I have laid, has been to gratifie your taste, and cheat the World, to prove a faithful Rogue to you.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: If this were true— but how can it be?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p:
I have so contriv'd, that Mellefont will presently, in the Caplain's habit, wait for Cynthia in your Dressing-Room: but I have put the change upon her, that she may be otherwhere employ'd— do you procure her Night-Gown, and with your Hoods tied over your face, meet him
in her stead, you may go privately by the back Stairs, and, unperceiv'd, there you may propose to reinstate him in his Uncle's favour; if he'll comply with your desires; his Case is desperate, and I believe he'll yield to any Conditions,— if not, here take this; you may employ it better, than in the Death of one who is nothing when not yours.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Thou can'st deceive every body,— nay, thou hast deceiv'd me; but 'tis as I would wish,— trusty Villain! I could worship thee.—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No more,— there want but a few Minutes of the time; and Mellefont's Love will carry him there before his hour.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: I go, I fly, incomparable, Maskwell!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: So, this was a pinch indeed, my invention was upon the Rack; and made discov'ry of her last Plot: I hope Cynthia, and my Chaplain will be ready, I'll prepare for the Expedition.

div.stage: Cynthia, and Lord Touchwood, come forward.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: Now, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Astonishment binds up my rage! Villany upon Villany! Heavens, what a long track of dark deceit has this discover'd! I am confounded when I look back, and want a Clue to guide me through the various mazes of unheard of Treachery. My Wife! Damnation! my Hell.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: My Lord, have patience, and be sensible how great our happiness is, that this discovery was not made too late.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: I thank you, yet it may be still too late, if we don't presently prevent the Execution of their plots;— ha, I'll do't, where's Mellefont, my poor injured Nephew,— how shall I make him ample satisfaction?—

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: I dare answer for him.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p:
I do him fresh wrong to question his forgivness; for I know him to be all goodness,— yet my Wise! Dam her,— she'll think to meet him in that Dressing-Room,— was't not so? And Maskwell will expect you in the Chaplain's Chamber,— for once, I'll add to my Plot too,— let us haste to find out, and inform my Nephew,
and do you quickly as you can, bring all the Company into this Gallery,— I'll expose the Strumpet, and the Villain.

div.stage: Enter Ld. Froth, and Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: By Heaven's, I have slept an Age,— Sir Paul, what a Clock is't? past Eight, on my Conscience, my Lady's is the most inviting Couch; and a slumber there, is the prettiest amusement! but where's all the Company?—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: The Company, gad'sbud, I don't know, my Lord, but here's the strangest Revolution, all turn'd topsie turvy; as I hope for Providence.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: O Heaven's, what's the matter? Where's my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: All turn'd topsie turvy, as sure as a Gun.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: How do you mean? My Wife!

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: The strangest posture of Affairs!

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: What, my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: No, no, I mean the Family,— your Lady's Affairs may be in a very good posture; I saw her go into the Garden with Mr. Brisk.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth
sp.p: How? where, when, what to do?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I suppose they have been laying their heads together.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Nay, only about Poetry, I suppose, my Lord; making Couplets.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: Couplets.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: O, here they come.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: My Lord, your humble Servant; Sir Paul yours,— the finest night!

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: My dear, Mr. Brisk and I have been Star-gazing, I don't know how long.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Does it not tire your Ladyship? are not you weary with looking up?

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Oh, no, I love it violently,— my dear you're melancholly.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: No, my dear; I'm but just awake.—

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Snuff some of my Spirit of Hartshorn.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: I've some of my own, thank you, my dear.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Well, I swear, Mr. Brisk, you understood Astronomy like an old Egyptian.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Not comparable to your Ladyship; you are the very Cynthia of the Skies, and Queen of Stars.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: That's because I've no light, but what's by Reflection from you, who are the Sun.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: O Jesu! Madam, you have Eclips'd me quite let me perish.— I can't answer that.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: No matter,— heark'ee, shall you and I make an Almanack together.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: With all my Soul,— your Ladyship has made me the Man in't already, I'm ●… full of the Wounds which you have given.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: O finely taken! I swear, now you are even with me, O Parnassus, you have an infinite deal of Wit..

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: So he has, gad'sbud, and so has your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: You tell me most surprizing things; bless me who would ever trust a man? O my heart akes for fear they should be all deceitful alike.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You need not fear, Madam, you have Charms to fix Inconstancy it self.

sp.speaker: L. P.
sp.p: O dear, you make me blush.

sp.speaker: Ld. Froth.
sp.p: Come my dear, shall we take leave of my Lord and Lady.

sp.speaker: Cynt.
sp.p: They'll wait upon your Lordship presently.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: Mr. Brisk. my Coach shall set you down.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What's the matter?

div.stage: A great shrick from the corner of the Stage.
Lady Touchwood runs out affrighted, my Lord after her, like a Parson.

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: O I'm betray'd,— save me, help me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Now what Evasion, Strumpet?

sp.speaker: L. Touch.
sp.p: Stand off, let me go, and Plagues, and Curses seize you all.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Go, and thy own Infamy pursue thee,— you stare as you were all amazed,— I don't wonder at it,— but too soon you'll know mine, and that Woman's shame.

div.stage: Enter Mellesont lugging in Maskwell from the other side of the Stage, Mellefont like a Parson.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, by Heaven you shall be seen,— Careless, your hand;— do you hold down your head? Yes, I am your Chaplain, look in the Face of your injur'd Friend; thou wonder of all Falshood.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Are you silent, Monster?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Good Heavens! how I believ'd and Lov'd this Man!— Take him hence, for he's a Disease to my Sight.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: Secure that manifold Villain.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Miracle of Ingratitude!

div.stage: They carry out Maskwell, who hangs down his head.

sp.speaker: Brisk
sp.p: This is all very surprizing, let me perish.

sp.speaker: L. Froth.
sp.p: You know I told you Saturn look'd a little more angry than usual.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: We'll think of punishment at leasure, but let me hasten to do Justice, in rewarding Virtue and wrong'd Innocence.— Nephew, I hope I have your pardon, and Cynthia's.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: We are your Lordships Creatures.

sp.speaker: Ld. Touch.
sp.p: And be each others comfort;— let me joyn your hands.— Unwearied Nights, and wishing Days attend you both; mutual Love, lasting Health, and Circling Joys, tread round each happy Year of your long Lives.
sp.l: Let secret Villany from hence be warn'd;
How e're in private, Mischiefs are conceiv'd,
Torture and shame attend their open Birth:
Like Vipers in the Womb, base Treach'ry lies,
Still gnawing that, whence, first it did arise;
No sooner born, but the Vile Parent dies.

div.head: EPILOGUE:
div.l: COuld Poets but forsee how Plays would take,
Then they could tell what Epilogues to make;
Whether to thank or blame their Audience▪ most:
But that late knowledge, does much hazard cost,
Till Dice are thrown, there's nothing won, nor lest.
So till the Thief has stoli'n, he cannot know
Whether he shall escape the Law, or no.
But Poets run much greater hazards far,
Than they who stand their Trials at the Barn;
The Law provides a curb for ' its own Fury,
And suffers Iudges to direct the Iury.
But in this Court, what difference does appear!
For every one's both Iudge and Iury here;
Nay, and what's worse, an Executioner.
All have a Right and Title to some part,
Each chusing that, in which he has most Art.
The dreadful men of Learning, all Confound,
Unless the Fable's good, and Moral sound.
The Vizor-Masks, that are in Pit and Gallery,
Approve, or Damn the Repartee and Rallery.
The Lady Criticks, who are better Read,
Enquire if Characters are nicely bred;
If the soft things are Penn'd and spoke with grace:
They Iudge of Action too, and Time, and Place;
In which, we do not doubt but they're discerning,
For that's a kind of Assignation Learning.
Beaus Iudge of Dress; the Witlings Iudge of Songs;
The Cuckoldom, of Ancient Right, to Cits belongs.
Thus poor Poets, the Favour are deny'd;
Even to make exceptions, when they're Try'd.
'Tis hard that they must every one admit;
Methinks I see some Faces in the Pit,
Which must of Consequence be Foes to Wit.
You who can Iudge, to Sentence may proceed;
But tho' he cannot Write, let him be freed
At least from their Contempt, who cannot Read.
